title: Kanban Fundamentals
description: Master Kanban fundamentals—visualize workflow, limit WIP, manage flow, make policies explicit, and implement feedback loops. Apply WIP limits and identify bottlenecks.
objectives: Identify the 5 core Kanban principles: visualize workflow, limit WIP, manage flow, make policies explicit, implement feedback loops
Apply WIP limits to improve team throughput and identify bottlenecks
Distinguish between pull systems (Kanban) and push systems (traditional task assignment)
Use Kanban boards as information radiators to visualize work status
Recognize when Kanban is more appropriate than iteration-based Agile (Scrum)
Understand flow metrics: cycle time, lead time, and cumulative flow diagrams

screens.headline: 12 experiments in progress. ZERO finished in 2 weeks. The team is busy but nothing's moving. What's broken?

items.label: Chaos
items.detail: Messy task list with 12 items all 'In Progress', stressed team

items.label: Kanban
items.detail: Clean board with 4 columns, WIP limits (In Progress: 3, Testing: 2), cards flowing

dialogue.text: Twelve experiments, zero results. I don't care about your 'process'—I care about FINISHED dishes. Fix this, Taylor.

screens.learningHook: Kanban isn't a to-do list—it's a SYSTEM for managing flow. Help Taylor implement Kanban principles to unclog the pipeline, make bottlenecks visible, and get experiments DONE.

screens.title: Kanban Implementation Scenarios
screens.instructions: For each challenge, identify the Kanban principle that applies and select Taylor's recommended action.

scenarios.title: Carlos's Constant Interruptions
description: Week 1: Carlos interrupts the team 8 times per day for status updates.
Team spends more time reporting than doing work.
Taylor: 'The Kanban board IS your status report.'
Carlos: 'I don't have time to check a board—just tell me.'

questions.question: Which Kanban principle addresses this visibility problem?

options.text: Limit Work In Progress (WIP)
Visualize the workflow (Kanban board as information radiator)
Implement feedback loops (retrospectives)
Make process policies explicit

feedback.correct: Visualize the workflow makes status visible to ALL stakeholders. Kanban board is an information radiator—Carlos can SEE status without interrupting.
feedback.incorrect: The problem is visibility—Carlos can't see status. Kanban board as information radiator solves this.

questions.question: What should Taylor do to address Carlos's interruptions?

options.text: Require team to send Carlos daily status emails
Set up monitor in Carlos's office showing live Kanban board
Schedule daily 5-minute status meeting with Carlos
Tell Carlos to trust the team and stop interrupting

feedback.correct: The board IS the status report. Put it where Carlos can see it—he checks the board instead of interrupting the team.
feedback.incorrect: Daily emails add overhead. The Kanban board IS the status report—make it visible to Carlos.

scenarios.title: Everything In Progress, Nothing Finishing
description: Week 1: In Progress column has 8 items. Testing has 2. Done has 0.
Maya: 'Every time I switch tasks, I lose 15 minutes getting back into focus.'

questions.question: Which Kanban principle addresses this WIP overload?

options.text: Limit Work In Progress (WIP)
Visualize the workflow
Manage flow (optimize throughput)
Implement feedback loops

feedback.correct: Limit WIP: Too much WIP = nothing finishes. Set max WIP per column to force completion before starting new work.
feedback.incorrect: High WIP = low completion rate. Limiting WIP forces focus and increases throughput.

options.text: 'Keep working on everything. We need all 8 done ASAP.'
'Set WIP limits: In Progress max = 3, Testing max = 2. Finish before starting new.'
'Add 2 more team members to handle the workload.'
'Cancel 5 experiments to reduce workload.'

feedback.correct: WIP limits force completion before starting new work. Reduces multitasking, increases throughput.
feedback.incorrect: Adding people doesn't fix high WIP—it adds more chaos. Limit WIP first.

scenarios.title: The Testing Bottleneck
description: Week 2: After WIP limits, a NEW problem emerges.
Board shows: In Progress 3/3 (at limit) | Testing 6 (way over limit of 2!) | Done 2
Dr. Foster (QA): 'I'm testing 6 dishes. I can't keep up. Chefs are waiting idle.'
Testing is a BOTTLENECK—work piles up there faster than processed.

questions.question: What should Taylor do when the Testing bottleneck is identified?

options.text: Increase WIP limit for Testing column to 6
Swarm: Team members help Dr. Foster with testing to clear the bottleneck
Remove WIP limits entirely to let work flow naturally
Move Dr. Foster to different team and hire new tester

feedback.correct: Swarm: When bottleneck appears, team rallies to help clear it. Bottleneck cleared in 90 minutes with team collaboration.
feedback.incorrect: Increasing WIP limit makes bottleneck WORSE by allowing more work to pile up. Swarm to clear it.

scenarios.title: Push System vs Pull System
description: Week 2 standup: Taylor assigns tasks: 'Maya, take truffle pasta. Devon, work on vegan burger.'
Maya interrupts: 'Taylor, STOP. You're assigning us work again—that's what we hated before.'
Taylor realizes she's still PUSHING work instead of letting team PULL.

questions.question: What's the difference between Push and Pull systems?

options.text: Push: Manager assigns tasks. Pull: Team members take tasks when they have capacity.
Push: Work moves automatically. Pull: Work requires approval.
Push: High WIP. Pull: Low WIP.
Push: Scrum. Pull: Kanban.

feedback.correct: Pull system empowers team to self-organize. They take work when ready, based on priority + capacity.
feedback.incorrect: Pull = team self-selects based on capacity. Push = manager assigns. Kanban uses pull.

options.text: 'From now on, PULL work from To Do when you finish. You decide priority.'
'I'll assign high-priority items, you pull low-priority.'
'Someone has to assign tasks. It's my job as Scrum Master.'
'Let's vote on who should assign tasks.'

feedback.correct: True pull system: Team pulls highest-priority item when ready. Priority is visual on board—no assignment needed.
feedback.incorrect: Assigning ANY tasks is still push. True pull: Team self-selects from prioritized board.

principles.name: Visualize the workflow
principles.explanation: Use Kanban board to make ALL work visible. Typical columns: To Do → In Progress → Testing → Done.

principles.name: Limit Work In Progress (WIP)
principles.explanation: Set maximum items per column. When column is full, NO new work until something exits.
principles.benefit: Forces completion, reduces multitasking, increases throughput

principles.name: Manage flow
principles.explanation: Optimize how work moves. Identify bottlenecks (where work piles up) and swarm to clear them.

principles.name: Make process policies explicit
principles.explanation: Document rules: What does Done mean? Who can pull work? How prioritize?
principles.benefit: Eliminates confusion. Everyone knows the rules.

principles.name: Implement feedback loops
principles.explanation: Regular retrospectives, flow metrics reviews, stakeholder demos.
principles.benefit: Kanban evolves based on data and team input.

columns.name: In Progress (Doing)
columns.purpose: Work being executed. LIMIT WIP to prevent multitasking.

columns.name: Testing (Validation)
columns.purpose: Work awaiting validation. Bottlenecks often appear here.

columns.name: Done
columns.purpose: Completed work. Measure of team throughput.

content.pmbokRef: Agile Practice Guide page 59; PMBOK 7th Ed page 189

pullSystem.definition: Team members self-select work from To Do when they have capacity

flowMetrics.cycleTime: Time from when work STARTS (In Progress) to DONE
flowMetrics.leadTime: Time from when work REQUESTED (To Do) to DONE (includes waiting)
flowMetrics.cumulativeFlowDiagram: Stacked chart showing how many items in each stage over time—healthy = parallel bands, unhealthy = bulging bands (bottlenecks)

comparison.scrum: Team commits to sprint goal upfront

correct.text: Week 1: 'WIP limits will slow us down!' Week 2: 'We finished 4 experiments vs 0 last week. I was wrong.'
I was drowning in 6 taste tests. The team swarmed and cleared it in 90 minutes. That's the power of making bottlenecks visible.

screens.title: Apply Kanban to Customer Support
screens.context: The support team handles complaints, refunds, and feedback. Current problem: 35 open tickets, 5-day average response time, customers angry. Help Jordan (support lead) adopt Kanban.

questions.question: Which column structure is BEST for customer support workflow?

options.text: To Do → Doing → Done (too generic)
New → Investigating → Awaiting Customer → Resolved → Closed (reflects support stages)

questions.question: What's the best pull rule for support?

options.text: Wait for manager to assign tickets (push)
Pull highest-priority ticket (severity + age) when you close one (pull)

screens.title: Kanban Fundamentals Mastery
screens.summary: You've learned Kanban fundamentals: visualize workflow, limit WIP, manage flow, make policies explicit, and implement feedback loops. You applied these to unclog the pipeline and quadruple completion rate.
takeaways: 5 Kanban principles: Visualize, Limit WIP, Manage flow, Explicit policies, Feedback loops
WIP limits force completion before starting new work—increases throughput
Kanban board = information radiator (visible status eliminates meetings)
Pull system (team self-selects) vs Push system (manager assigns)
Bottlenecks = stages where work piles up—swarm to clear them
Kanban = continuous flow (no iterations), best for unpredictable work

characterClosing.text: I thought Kanban was just sticky notes on a wall. It's actually a rigorous flow management system. Completion rate went from 0 to 4 experiments/week. I'm sold.
